item.title: For China, a Missile Defense System in South Korea Spells a Failed Courtship
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in Beijing in 2013.
item.description: South Korea showed that it was embracing its alliance with Washington more than ever, and that it would rely less on China to keep North Korea at bay.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Widespread Flooding in China Kills Over 160, Providing a Test for Leaders
item.description: The country’s flood defenses have faltered in the past, but Prime Minister Li Keqiang has said that the government is better prepared this year.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Dozens Reported Dead in South Sudan Capital After Rival Forces Battle
item.media:description: Vice President Riek Machar, left, speaking to reporters with President Salva Kiir, center, and Second Vice President James Wani Igga before shooting erupted outside the presidential palace in Juba on Friday.
item.media:credit: Charles Atiki Lomodong/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Heavy exchanges of gunfire rolled across neighborhoods of Juba, with unconfirmed reports that up to 150 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN and JOSH KRON

item.title: ‘This Has Pushed a Button’: Killings in Kenya Ignite National Outcry
item.media:description: A priest spread incense on Friday during a funeral Mass in Nairobi for Willie Kimani, a human rights lawyer, and Joseph Muiruri, a taxi driver, who were abducted and killed along with Josphat Mwenda, a client of Mr. Kimani’s.
item.description: The case of a lawyer, his last known client and a taxi driver, all last seen in police custody but later found dead in a river, has exploded like few others in Kenya.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Family of Marie Colvin, Slain U.S. Journalist, Sues Syria
item.media:description: Marie Colvin of The Sunday Times of London during a service in November 2010 at St. Bride’s Church in London.
item.description: The complaint contends that Syrian officials worked in concert to locate, track and target journalists like Ms. Colvin, who was killed in an artillery strike in 2012.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: ISIS Shoots Down Helicopter in Syria, Killing 2 Russians
item.description: The episode occurred east of the city of Palmyra when the Russians had exhausted their ammunition firing in support of Syrian government forces.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Obama Tells NATO That ‘Europe Can Count On’ the U.S.
item.media:description: President Obama in Warsaw on Saturday at a NATO summit meeting with, from left, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France.
item.description: The president assured alliance partners that threats from terrorism and an aggressive Russia would not deter the United States.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and RICK LYMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: NATO Unity, Tested by Russia, Shows Some Cracks
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, center; Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, third from right; President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, second from right; and other leaders at the NATO summit meeting in Warsaw on Friday.
item.description: At a summit meeting of the Atlantic alliance, the first after Britain’s vote to withdraw from the European Union, leaders brought differing agendas for dealing with Moscow.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Bulls in Spain Kill 2 and Gore 2 Others
item.description: A professional matador was killed in the ring in front of spectators, and another man died in a bull run, while two others were gored.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Mayor Fluent in Twitter Embodies a New Canadian Diversity
item.media:description: “I like research; I do the data. I’m not the guy kissing the babies.” NAHEED NENSHI
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.description: Naheed Nenshi, the groundbreaking Muslim mayor of Calgary, is known for his acid Twitter retorts and for revitalizing the city. His faith rarely comes up.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Returns Home After Heart Surgery in London
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, shown on March 23 in Islamabad, has returned to Pakistan after having heart surgery in London.
item.description: The convalescence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has done nothing to soften the political opposition he faces over the so-called Panama Papers.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Raid on Indonesian Food Stall Prompts Fears of Fundamentalism
item.media:description: Saeni, center, the owner of the food stall that was raided, with her daughter Elita and her husband, Alex, at their home in Serang, Indonesia. Last month, Ms. Saeni was accused of violating a local bylaw against serving daytime meals during Ramadan.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: While the case has become a symbol of what some see as “creeping Islamization,” others insisted that the country was not becoming more religious.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Inside China’s Secret 23-Day Detention of a Foreign Nonprofit Chief
item.media:description: Peter Dahlin, a Swedish citizen, in Chiang Mai, Thailand, in May. Mr. Dahlin was deported from China after being detained and interrogated for 23 days by the country’s Ministry of State Security.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The group that Peter Dahlin, a Swede, helped found is the type of organization that President Xi Jinping has said is undermining the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China

item.title: If a Carrot for Jordan Works, Syrian Refugees Will Stay Put
item.media:description: Ammar Samir, 20, from Syria, second from left, has a work permit from Jordan. He works in a bakery in Amman with other men from Egypt and Iraq.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Jordan agreed to take in thousands of Syrian refugees in return for giant interest-free loans from the World Bank. But is it robbing Peter to pay Paul?
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Contest for British Premier Flares Over Claims on Motherhood
item.media:description: Andrea Leadsom, the energy minister, after giving television interviews in London on Thursday.
item.description: One contender seemed to suggest in a newspaper interview that being a mother would make her a better leader than her rival, who does not have children.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Iran, Once Quiet About Its Casualties in Syria and Iraq, Now Glorifies Them
item.media:description: At the recent Tehran International Book Fair, ordinary Iranians could pose as “defenders of the shrines” astride a military motorcycle in front of a billboard showing a battered street in Syria.
item.description: The reason for the change, analysts say, is not rooted in newfound dedication to transparency, but in a desire to sustain Iranian support for Syria’s government.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Abdul Sattar Edhi, Pakistan’s ‘Father Teresa,’ Dies at 88
item.media:description: Abdul Sattar Edhi, in 2002, feeding children at a care center named for him in Karachi, Pakistan.
item.description: Mr. Edhi set up a foundation that runs nursing homes, orphanages, soup kitchens and family planning centers — all free of charge — as well as Pakistan’s largest ambulance service.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Man Survives Terrorist Attack in Bangladesh, but Is in Custody as a Suspect
item.media:description: Bangladeshi police officers guard a checkpoint where flowers have been left by well-wishers near the Holey Artisan Bakery, the scene of a fatal attack and siege, in Dhaka last weekend.
item.description: Tahmid Khan, a college student, was wrongly suspected of being in league with the militants, his family and friends say. They now fear for his safety.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Cartoon of Obama Is Condemned as Anti-Semitic in Spain
item.media:description: Police officers on patrol in Seville, Spain, on Friday, a day before a scheduled visit by President Obama.
item.description: As part of a protest against President Obama’s visit to Spain, the United Left posted a drawing of him hugging a caricature of Jewish man and slipping him money.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Migration to Greece by the Aegean Sea Has Plummeted, U.N. Says
item.media:description: The Kara Tepe refugee camp in Mytilene, Greece.
item.description: The figures suggest that a deal brokered by the European Union with Turkey has worked, although human rights groups have raised concerns.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Obama Rebukes Poland’s Right-Wing Government
item.media:description: President Obama and President Andrzej Duda of Poland after speaking at the NATO summit meeting in Warsaw on Friday.
item.description: President Obama expressed concern over the Polish government’s constitutional crisis as a NATO summit meeting began in Warsaw.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Factional Fighting Breaks Out in South Sudan’s Capital
item.media:description: Journalists waited on a podium after the sounds of gunshots rang out before a news conference by President Salva Kiir of South Sudan on Friday at the Presidential State House in Juba.
item.description: Gunfire broke out for a second straight day on Friday, threatening a truce just days before the country’s independence anniversary.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN and JOSH KRON

item.title: The Interpreter: A Central Conflict of 21st-Century Politics: Who Belongs?
item.media:description: A “Leave” campaigner and a supporter of “Remain” in London last weekend.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Michael Ignatieff, a former party leader in Canada, describes tensions between those who see immigration as a universal right, and those who regard it as a limited gift.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Palestinians Stabbing Less but Shooting More, as Israel Cracks Down
item.media:description: Bolstered security at checkpoints between Israel and the West Bank last month, two days after the Sarona complex attack in Tel Aviv.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Experts see a parallel surge in deadly mayhem that seems to be “inspired” by Islamic State attacks in Brussels, San Bernardino and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: In China, Relatives Await Word on Detained Rights Lawyers After a Year
item.media:description: The wives of human rights lawyers who were detained a year ago wore dresses with their husbands’ names to the state prosecutor’s offices in Beijing on Monday.
item.description: Nearly 250 human rights lawyers and activists were detained last year, and this week loved ones of those still in custody began to speak out more vocally.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: May and Leadsom Face Off to Become Prime Minister
item.media:description: A view of the City of London, the financial heart of Britain.
item.description: The next premier will be a woman, consumer confidence has tanked and the trans-Atlantic alliance may be facing its most important moment since the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Typhoon Nepartak Heads for China After Killing 2 in Taiwan
item.media:description: A street in Taitung, Taiwan, on Friday after Typhoon Nepartak tore through.
item.description: The storm hit Taiwan as a Category 4 typhoon, the second-most powerful category, with wind gusts reaching 140 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Taiwan Train Explosion Wasn’t Organized Terrorism, Government Says
item.media:description: A bomb squad officer entering the commuter train where a bombing occurred on Thursday. The episode is likely to revive concerns about security on public transportation in Taiwan.
item.description: At least 25 people were injured in the blast, which Taiwan’s premier said was most likely the work of “an individual person.” A news agency said a suspect had been identified.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: What in the World: A Fire Monkey Can Usher In Chaos. So Can 600 or So Macaques.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Ben Sklar for The New York Times, Eric Thayer/Reuters
item.description: This is a rare Year of the Fire Monkey, an occasion often associated with chaos. Just ask a village in China that’s been overrun by little, loud primates.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: Bulgarians Hope Che Guevara and Brigitte Bardot Can Save Their Village
item.media:description: Stefana Gospodinova and her mule with murals of themselves and Brigitte Bardot, a well-known animal lover, in the Bulgarian village of Staro Zhelezare.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Two artists want their murals of famous people — alongside portraits of residents — to help start a revival in Staro Zhelezare, population 400.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: What in the World: Why Finland’s Newborns Sleep in Cardboard Cribs
item.media:description: A baby in the Kela maternity package box, which is distributed to new parents in Finland.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: “Baby boxes” were introduced in the 1930s to ensure that every infant had a safe place to nap (and that Mom got a checkup). And they worked.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Teenagers in Japan Can Finally Vote. But Will They?
item.media:description: Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party posted a manga comic on its website aimed at 18-year-olds, featuring a high school girl who decides to vote as a way of attracting the attention of a boy she likes. The comic was criticized as sexist on social media.
item.description: In a nation whose politics are dominated by older voters, apathy threatens to dilute the power of newly enfranchised 18- and 19-year-olds.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Indian Forces Kill 10 During Kashmir Protests Over Separatist’s Death
item.media:description: Relatives on Saturday mourned Burhan Wani, a top commander for the Kashmiri rebel group Hizbul Mujahedeen, who was killed Friday during a shootout with Indian forces in southern Kashmir.
item.description: Protesters attacked more than 70 government offices and police posts in parts of Kashmir, including Srinagar, the main city, setting fire to some structures.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Opinion: Why the E.U. Had It Coming
item.description: Frustration with the European Union has been building for decades.
item.dc:creator: TIM PARKS

item.title: Editorial: Iraq War Lies, 13 Years Later
item.media:description: Tony Blair at a press conference in London on Wednesday.
item.description: An official British report has reminded both Britons and Americans how lies and ideology can lead nations into war.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Dallas Shooting
item.description: Uncle Sam pleads for calm.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
